abstracts.cdata!:
The supplemental credit to the Second
            Structural Adjustment Credit Project will provide Madagascar
            with fast-disbursing foreign exchange to partially
            compensate for lower export earnings, and higher import
            needs in 2000/2001, due to the three cyclones that partly
            devastated the country recently. These have created
            unanticipated financing needs that would endanger the
            government's reform effort, otherwise proceeding on
            track. Counterpart funds generated will assist the
            government in its planned reconstruction effort. Benefits
            will maintain macroeconomic stability, while meeting
            pressing reconstruction requirements. However, risks relate
            to the financing need being larger than anticipated,
            capacity constraints in the public sector, and the
            non-transparent use of funds. Appropriate supervision, and
            monitoring will address these risks. Although not targeted
            at the poor, the credit would assist the poor by helping the
            government contain inflation, providing foreign exchange for
            key imports - mainly rice - and contributing resources for
            the restoration of basic services in the affected areas. The
            supplemental credit will be disbursed in one tranche.
